{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3291423,"name":"","username":"arm","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ce73a5/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-22T15:19:59.395Z","cooked":"

I’ve been struggling to understand Phoenix 6’s units, and I think it’s because of my general lack of understanding of motors. Phoenix 5 would give us the motor’s position using TalonFX.getSelectedSensorPosition(), which would return “encoder ticks” or “raw sensor units”, which I understood as so:

  • the internal rotor has binary-like “markings” on it
  • when the rotor rotates, a light sensor can sense how many markings have been viewed
  • every new marking seen is the same as an encoder tick

I understood that from this explanation. So the way that we would measure wheel rotations dividing the total number of encoder ticks by the ticks-per-rotation ratio.

Now, Phoenix 6 uses TalonFX.getPosition() which returns the “position of the device in mechanism rotations.” I was explained that “mechanism rotations” means rotor rotations / SensorToMechanismRatio. I’m assuming a mechanism rotation is more of an abstract term, so for example, in my case, it would be the wheel making a full rotation. So is a rotor rotation the same as an encoder tick, and the SensorToMechanismRatio is the same as the number of ticks in one mechanism rotation?

Or is a rotor rotation one full motor shaft rotation, and SensorToMechanismRatio measures how many shaft rotations it takes for one mechanism rotation?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-01-22T15:24:32.075Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":540,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":2730.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":451478,"topic_slug":"understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/how-do-encoders-work/114786/2","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"How do Encoders work?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63482,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6/451478/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3291433,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-22T15:40:48.894Z","cooked":"

Phoenix 6 operates fundamentally in Motor shaft rotations.

Mechanism is a ratio of Motor shaft rotation / the gear ratio of said user defined mechanism to get the final output rotation.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-01-22T15:45:26.731Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":132,"readers_count":131,"score":86.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":451478,"topic_slug":"understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6/451478/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3291440,"name":"","username":"arm","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ce73a5/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-22T15:49:41.244Z","cooked":"

So the rotor rotation is the same as a shaft rotation, and the SensorToMechanismRatio is what we define as the number of shaft rotations in one mechanism rotation (in other words, a gear ratio). Did I understand correctly?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-01-22T15:49:41.244Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":33.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":451478,"topic_slug":"understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12688,"username":"JohnFogarty","name":"John Fogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63482,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/understanding-motor-mechanisms-and-phoenix-6/451478/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3291442,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-22T15:51:15.368Z","cooked":"

Yes you understand correctly.

You no longer have to do manual conversion math for internal sensor “ticks”
